description: From Middle English stameren, from Old English stamerian, from Proto-West Germanic *stamrōn, from Proto-Germanic *stamrōną (“to stammer”). Compare German stammeln, Dutch stameren, Old Norse stammr. Doublet of stumble.

entries.meaning: The involuntary repetition of a sound in speech.
examples: She said goodbye in a stammer.

entries.meaning: A speech defect whereby someone speaks with a stammer

verbs.description: stammer (third-person singular simple present stammers, present participle stammering, simple past and past participle stammered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To keep repeating a particular sound involuntarily during speech.
(transitive) To utter with a stammer, or with timid hesitancy.
examples: He blushed, and stammered a few words of apology.
